content:
Hi :)

Depending on the color scheme, there are emojis that are nearly invisible, for example the current status emoji of @Alya Abbott:
Screenshot-from-2021-09-22-10-42-37.png

Maybe we could make emojis stand out more by adding a small shadow (dark for the light theme and light for the dark theme)?

Hmm interesting.

What emoji is that? (… A tangent: it looks like we don't give status emoji a tooltip to tell you the name you can use to enter it yourself. We should.)
It’s the Twitter :water_buffalo:.

Greg Price said:

(… A tangent: it looks like we don't give status emoji a tooltip to tell you the name you can use to enter it yourself. We should.)

#19821

Oh interesting. Another thing here is that the glyph is slightly smaller where it appears in the sidebar… and a lot blurrier.

image.png
image.png

In the sidebar version of that emoji, I really can't tell what it's trying to show at all, even after knowing its name. In the version in the message list, I can make out the :water_buffalo:'s horns and head and legs and general body shape.

Robert (ro-i) said:

Hi :)

Depending on the color scheme, there are emojis that are nearly invisible, for example the current status emoji of Alya Abbott:
Screenshot-from-2021-09-22-10-42-37.png

But also I'm not reproducing this issue! So something subtler seems to be going on.

Switching to night mode, I see

image.png

That's in Chrome on Linux. @Robert (ro-i) what browser did you see this issue in?
You need to change your emoji set to Twitter.
Ah, I see. Now I understand what you meant by "the Twitter $emoji" above :)

Anyway, my feeling is that the important part of the user list is the name, and we don’t need to do anything special to emphasize the emoji if the user picks one that happens not to be particularly visible under some circumstances.
Does that emoji look equally unreadable in a message, or a reaction?

I don't think I agree that the emoji isn't an important part of that display. Looking at the right sidebar now here on czo, there aren't a lot of status emoji, and many of those people do have are decorative. But we've heard feedback that a similar feature in Slack is a useful way in many organizations for people to signal things like in meetings / working remotely / traveling. So we want them to be visible.
If this is a problem of one emoji's glyph in one emojiset, though, I wouldn't want to try to apply a general design change as an attempted solution.

I looked at Twitter with https://twitter.com/search?q=water+buffalo in their dark mode, to see how the same glyph turns out there.

It shows up fine. The key difference is that their dark-mode background is a lot darker than ours.
Screen-Shot-2021-09-23-at-12.36.47-PM.png

I’ve never liked how our dark theme design uses a lighter background with darker boxes on top of it. Most dark themes do the opposite.

But yes, there are just a handful of Twitter emoji with that shade of gray.

Anders Kaseorg said:

Anyway, my feeling is that the important part of the user list is the name, and we don’t need to do anything special to emphasize the emoji if the user picks one that happens not to be particularly visible under some circumstances.

But the visibility also is an issue in normal messages... So I thought about some kind of shadow for all appearances of emojis... :water_buffalo:
Its also an issue with penguins on transparent background :sad:
and that hurts ;)
See
My advice is that if you don’t like the Twitter emoji set, switch to Google Modern.

Anders Kaseorg said:

I’ve never liked how our dark theme design uses a lighter background with darker boxes on top of it. Most dark themes do the opposite.

Yeah, I'm looking at GitHub in dark mode now and it's also a lot darker than ours.

It does give the text inputs a darker background still, same as we do. (Though our text inputs are still much lighter than the main background on either GitHub or Twitter.) But most other things are lighter.
I’m very reluctant to endorse a proposal to make emoji more eye-popping—there are more than enough party parrots in the world.
But an overall redesign of the background colors would be a general improvement if done well.

Yeah, I really think we could do something... Either a small, tiny shadow for emojis or another background color maybe... Because neither water buffaloes nor penguins (for example) are really visible:
Screenshot-from-2021-09-23-21-57-28.png
I think that would also help regarding accessibility...

Anders Kaseorg said:

But an overall redesign of the background colors would be a general improvement if done well.

Yeah, I think the two big reasons it'd be good to have dark mode be darker are:

  • to actually fulfill the point of a dark mode: let the screen emit less light (so it's less disturbing in a dark room, and so it potentially consumes less battery);
  • to have better contrast with text.

Sure, there may be a good balance to find. Material Design explicitly warns against making the background too dark (like true black) in dark mode, which I think is interesting. From a doc:

A dark theme uses dark grey, rather than black, as the primary surface color for components. Dark grey surfaces can express a wider range of color, elevation, and depth, because it's easier to see shadows on grey (instead of black).

Dark grey surfaces also reduce eye strain, as light text on a dark grey surface has less contrast than light text on a black surface.

Chris Bobbe said:

Material Design explicitly warns against making the background too dark (like true black) in dark mode

For a Material-influenced example, I just took a look at Gmail's dark mode.

Their background isn't black, but it is again a lot darker than ours: #111111 generally, and as dark as #040404 in some areas (like for read conversations in the main/conversation-list view.) Ours is #222d39. Even in the message text input where it's somewhat darker, it's #1b242d.
GitHub's is #0d1117.
Twitter uses true black, #000.
